div.p: Most illustrious man, I received your letter yesterday, in which you informed me, among other things, about the marriage of Josias and Elisabeth, which I hope the Lord God will bless through Jesus Christ; I congratulate you all. I understood what Mr. Haler wrote. At the moment, I do not have the leisure to write to him; but I ask you to write back that I will soon return to you and that I am now engaged in matters that pertain entirely to the whole Christian republic; for it is certainly so. I sent a man to Italy to friends who wrote that they did not know where I was staying, and therefore they sent few letters to me; I sent another to the masked fathers. Therefore, expect lengthy letters from me soon. Now I only affirm this: it is true, as you say, that war has been declared between the Emperor and the King; so everyone affirms. In Cremona, a horrid persecution had arisen against the members of Christ; but Mr. Fernandus Gonzaga completely removed it by the grace of God, so that those poor brothers can now breathe again.

Three times a week I began to preach, but good God, with what rage from the impious; for they entirely hoped I would never return again. But it troubles them that I am one who cannot preach calmly and spare the Antichrist. And who among those who feel Christ can spare him? I affirm that I am here in some danger, but I trust in the Lord. I commend to you from my heart my nephews, that is, that you often urge them to be diligent, and the teacher to be strict; in this matter, you can do nothing more pleasing for me. Whatever happens, I will return to you as soon as possible and bring translations and some other things. Farewell and be well, most excellent man. Greet all the brothers for me.
Add a word to Mr. Haler, that he should write to Mr. Viret to send you the booklets and images that were brought to him from Geneva. Vicosoprano, 8th October 1551.
To the most illustrious Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, etc.
